statement.tex: %text Find $\dfrac{dy}{dx}$ if \[ y = \cot^{-1}\left[ \dfrac{\sqrt{1+\sin x} + \sqrt{1-\sin x}}{\sqrt{1+\sin x} - \sqrt{1-\sin x}}\right] \] %

\\ %text \textbf{Picking a line-of-attack} Shown below are two possible ways of starting to solve the problem. One of them \underline\text{is more elegant} than the other. \underline\text{Which one}? %
\\ %text What will be get when we rationalize \[ \qquad P(x) = \left[ \dfrac{\sqrt{1+\sin x} + \sqrt{1-\sin x}}{\sqrt{1+\sin x} - \sqrt{1-\sin x}}\right] \] as decided in Step 1? %
\\ %text Given that \[ P(x) = \frac{\sin x}{1-\cos x} \], what will $\frac{dy}{dx}$ be? Remember, \[ y = \cot^{-1} P(x) \] %

reason.tex:
%text \[ P(x) = \left[ \dfrac{\sqrt{1+\sin x} + \sqrt{1-\sin x}}{\sqrt{1+\sin x} - \sqrt{1-\sin x}}\right]\] looks like a complicated expression.
You can try differentiating it. But the algebra could get very complicated very quickly.
Hence, try instead to \underline\text{simplify P(x)} using rationalization.
If P(x) can be turned into something simpler, then all subsequent work will also get easier. %
